messages: 9bd0cc47db95ddf15b8d9f8e62c64c6e (09:39): the way to do it is ctrl-w L
9bd0cc47db95ddf15b8d9f8e62c64c6e (09:39): this will move the current split to the extreme right
9bd0cc47db95ddf15b8d9f8e62c64c6e (09:39): sorry, I didn't see the question until after the fact.
0c40c1bf00d55d35ab17baf2cbec36f8 (09:40): Neat.
1079c8af06fa795e25e94abf8a7ceb3e (10:00): why does gg 25 bring me to line 26
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:01): uh, did you really type g, g, space, 2, 5?
1079c8af06fa795e25e94abf8a7ceb3e (10:02): yes
1079c8af06fa795e25e94abf8a7ceb3e (10:02): this has been happening for a while
1079c8af06fa795e25e94abf8a7ceb3e (10:02): no space
0c40c1bf00d55d35ab17baf2cbec36f8 (10:02): gg25 should take you to the top of the file and start a count of 25.
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:02): if you didn't type a space, don't say something with space
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:02): shouldn't do anything until you give another command
1079c8af06fa795e25e94abf8a7ceb3e (10:03): tpope: ohhh... lol.  i get what you're saying now. sorry
1079c8af06fa795e25e94abf8a7ceb3e (10:03): gg25<CR>
1079c8af06fa795e25e94abf8a7ceb3e (10:03): gives me line 26
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:03): there is your problem
1079c8af06fa795e25e94abf8a7ceb3e (10:03): <ENTER>
1079c8af06fa795e25e94abf8a7ceb3e (10:03): thanks, tpope
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:03): <ENTER> is a completely separate command
1079c8af06fa795e25e94abf8a7ceb3e (10:03): interesting
0c40c1bf00d55d35ab17baf2cbec36f8 (10:04): 25G also works.
1079c8af06fa795e25e94abf8a7ceb3e (10:04): yep, works great
1079c8af06fa795e25e94abf8a7ceb3e (10:04): thanks, guys
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:04): yeah I like G better too
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:04): repeating feels slow... I like Vd better than dd
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:05): well if you edit by feeling...
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:05): you're saying I should take some measurements tpope?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:06): I'm saying there's no sane way Vd could be faster than d
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:06): I'm saying there's no sane way Vd could be faster than d
0c40c1bf00d55d35ab17baf2cbec36f8 (10:06): I can't see how Vd can be faster than dd.
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:06): shift, v, d versus the same key twice
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:06): a key on the home row
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:07): you might could make a case for G versus gg but most people gravitate towards the latter as they become more experienced
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:09): I just have experience with stepmania and therein the most difficult combinations are repeats

13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:10): it is possible to, within shorter time than can be heard, pound shift, v, d in a single motion faster than a finger could have time to lift and hit d a second time
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:10): not saying I have mastered this or anything
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:10): because you tend to hit double keys too fast and miss the beat
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:11): tpope: you play stepmania??
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:11): once upon a time
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:11): you don't sound too proud
da406977df3ed5f876a383c133f3e859 (10:11): is there anyway to setup an autocmd (or any method) to hilight the current line?
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:12): depends on if you mean syntax highlight
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:12): orphean, :help 'cursorline'
da406977df3ed5f876a383c133f3e859 (10:13): excellent. thank you guys.
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:16): praetis, it's just kinda silly without a mat
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:17): tpope: but you can go so much faster and play so much longer
09dd385295bbbceb3983f0de471e6ef0 (10:17): gg is more popular than G for experienced users?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:17): praetis, if I wanted to spend time making repetitive keyboard strokes I'd switch to notepad :)
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:18): desrt, well based on my own observations and comments in the channel
09dd385295bbbceb3983f0de471e6ef0 (10:18): harsh words :p
09dd385295bbbceb3983f0de471e6ef0 (10:18): i even 1G
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:18): tpope: that's what vim needs, a music background synchronized to your keypresses
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:19): one reason for gg being better might be that you have to reach up to type numbers and then back down to shift for G
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:20): or otherwise twist up your hand with your pinky at the ready
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:21): yeah it starts with gg over 1G
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:21): then you discover 2gg
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:23): I'm wondering, why bother have space, backspace, and enter in normal mode when you have hjkl?
8bece2647a39db763401c1e98abe5854 (10:23): praetis: I don't.
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:24): yeah, I was just thinking, people who jump around lines a lot, why not :map <space> gg
8bece2647a39db763401c1e98abe5854 (10:24): praetis: I don't even have up/down/left/right in normal mode. they're bound to things like next buffer previous buffer.
8bece2647a39db763401c1e98abe5854 (10:24): space being zj and backspace being zk would be fun
8bece2647a39db763401c1e98abe5854 (10:24): or { and } would be nice.
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:25): praetis, mainly because space is too easy to hit by accident
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:25): if you want, by all means try it
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:26): Jerub: yeah, I actually unmapped my arrow keys to keep myself off them :)
8bece2647a39db763401c1e98abe5854 (10:26): praetis: making them useful as something else is the obvious conclusion :p
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:27): I'm gonna have to really think about this.  I get three new keys reachable at home row to do whatever I want!  Oh, the choices...
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:31): heh, and ctrl-n and ctrl-p, though I'm trying to get the hang of those for terminal and whatever brief moments I may find myself on emacs
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:32): now this is interesting, why's Ctrl-J also move down? Five different commands for that?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:33): praetis: C-J is linefeed
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:33): you might not want to try C-M
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:34): C-M is carriage return
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:34): the same as the enter key
13d7d168f19c177db483c695588e476c (10:34): oh I see, j and enter are not the same

9bd0cc47db95ddf15b8d9f8e62c64c6e (10:35): I have a professor who remapped the f key, so every time I try to find a letter on the same line to jump to it, the computers at school do something completely unexpected.
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (10:35): who in their right mind remaps the f key for *everybody*

9bd0cc47db95ddf15b8d9f8e62c64c6e (10:36): well, he was being "nice" and giving all us students the benefit of his highly custimized .vimrc file with all it's enhancements so we could look at it and use the enhancements and whatnot.
9bd0cc47db95ddf15b8d9f8e62c64c6e (10:37): only problem was that he remapped things I use all the time.
4a85c54f6f47d364cbf03d0191e7881c (11:00): what font do you use in gvim? (if you use it of course)
